content.raw:
Testing what values --zscore gives for simpleseg after transformation, using pdb:

```
#!python

(Pdb) tracks_means
array([ 0.44068674,  0.44068674])
(Pdb) tracks_vars
array([ 0.19420484,  0.19420484])
```

Before transformation:

```
#!python

(Pdb) float_data[:,track]
array([ 0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        , ...,  0.88137358,
        0.88137358,  0.88137358], dtype=float32)
```

After transformation:

```
#!python

(Pdb) float_data[:,track]
array([-0.99999988, -0.99999988, -0.99999988, ...,  1.00000012,
        1.00000012,  1.00000012], dtype=float32)
```

Running --zscore with simpleseg's touchstone's input.master, we find oscillatory non-convergence.

If we try to 'manually' implement z-score (eg, switch all 0's in simpleseg's test tracks to -1 and leave 1s as is) and set ``distribution=norm`` (eg no asinh transform), and use simpleseg's touchstone's input.master, we get convergence.

The difference between the params files at round 5 is as follows:


```
#!python

50c50
< mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9998921156e-01 
---
> mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999564886e-01 
52c52
< mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9921458960e-01 
---
> mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9849396944e-01 
56c56
< mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 -3.3236573493e-09 
---
> mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 6.1064490353e-08 
58c58
< mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack1 1 1.0000000000e+00 
---
> mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999994040e-01 
62c62
< mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999988079e-01 
---
> mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999946356e-01 
64c64
< mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9998778105e-01 
---
> mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9996304512e-01 
70c70
< covar_testtrack1 1 4.2357182650e-08 
---
> covar_testtrack1 1 1.4555391203e-07 
72c72
< covar_testtrack2 1 5.0001829863e-01 
---
> covar_testtrack2 1 5.0003665686e-01 

```
content.html:
Testing what values --zscore gives for simpleseg after transformation, using pdb:

(Pdb) tracks_means
array([ 0.44068674,  0.44068674])
(Pdb) tracks_vars
array([ 0.19420484,  0.19420484])

Before transformation:

(Pdb) float_data[:,track]
array([ 0.        ,  0.        ,  0.        , ...,  0.88137358,
        0.88137358,  0.88137358], dtype=float32)

After transformation:

(Pdb) float_data[:,track]
array([-0.99999988, -0.99999988, -0.99999988, ...,  1.00000012,
        1.00000012,  1.00000012], dtype=float32)

Running --zscore with simpleseg's touchstone's input.master, we find oscillatory non-convergence.

If we try to 'manually' implement z-score (eg, switch all 0's in simpleseg's test tracks to -1 and leave 1s as is) and set distribution=norm (eg no asinh transform), and use simpleseg's touchstone's input.master, we get convergence.

The difference between the params files at round 5 is as follows:

50c50
< mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9998921156e-01 
---
> mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999564886e-01 
52c52
< mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9921458960e-01 
---
> mean_seg0_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9849396944e-01 
56c56
< mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 -3.3236573493e-09 
---
> mean_seg1_subseg0_testtrack2 1 6.1064490353e-08 
58c58
< mean_seg2_subseg0_testtrack1 1 1.0000000000e+00

< mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack1 1 9.9999988079e-01

64c64
< mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9998778105e-01 
---
> mean_seg3_subseg0_testtrack2 1 9.9996304512e-01 
70c70
< covar_testtrack1 1 4.2357182650e-08 
---
> covar_testtrack1 1 1.4555391203e-07 
72c72
< covar_testtrack2 1 5.0001829863e-01 
---
> covar_testtrack2 1 5.0003665686e-01

content.raw:
Due to changes in the way observation/window generation has been re-routed, the z-score code will probably have to be rerouted into ``run.py``, likely ahead of ``queue_train`` (probably directly after ``train_windows`` are generated). Track means and vars need to be calculated ahead of the transform application, and passed along accordingly.

I also found an issue with the way multiple genome data archives is implemented--``track_means`` and ``track_vars`` should have an extra dimension (eg [genomedata_archive][track] instead of just [track]) and this should propagate accordingly in the transform. This might need to be turned into a dictionary for organisation purposes.
content.html:
Due to changes in the way observation/window generation has been re-routed, the z-score code will probably have to be rerouted into run.py, likely ahead of queue_train (probably directly after train_windows are generated). Track means and vars need to be calculated ahead of the transform application, and passed along accordingly.

I also found an issue with the way multiple genome data archives is implemented--track_means and track_vars should have an extra dimension (eg [genomedata_archive][track] instead of just [track]) and this should propagate accordingly in the transform. This might need to be turned into a dictionary for organisation purposes.

update.description:
This pull request separates the --zscore option from [pull request #68](#!/hoffmanlab/segway/pull-requests/68/gaussian-mixture-models/). Note: I have not changed anything about the zscore functionality except attempting to adapt it for the multiple genomedata case.

It was suggested to move the zscore option to a separate distribution, ie, ```DISTRIBUTION_ZSCORE_ASINH```.
update.title: Using --zscore to normalise datatracks

content.raw: @mlibbrecht Oh, I think I understand now. Thanks for the explanation!
content.html: @mlibbrecht Oh, I think I understand now. Thanks for the explanation!

content.raw:
It will have that normal distribution shape if the data came from a normal distribution in the first place. If the original distribution had a different shape, that shape will be retained. 

All that's happening is subtracting the mean from each data point and dividing the result by the standard deviation -- that's it.
content.html:
It will have that normal distribution shape if the data came from a normal distribution in the first place. If the original distribution had a different shape, that shape will be retained.

All that's happening is subtracting the mean from each data point and dividing the result by the standard deviation -- that's it.

content.raw: @mlibbrecht Please correct me if I'm wrong, but under a 'z-score distribution', won't both low and high outliers have high absolute z-score values and values closer to the mean be ~0?
content.html: @mlibbrecht Please correct me if I'm wrong, but under a 'z-score distribution', won't both low and high outliers have high absolute z-score values and values closer to the mean be ~0?

content.raw:
GMTK shouldn't have any issue with negative values. We have used --zscore for the last round of annotations without issue.

What do you mean by "modify the shape" of the data? It will shift and scale the values, but not change the shape of the distribution.
content.html:
GMTK shouldn't have any issue with negative values. We have used --zscore for the last round of annotations without issue.

What do you mean by "modify the shape" of the data? It will shift and scale the values, but not change the shape of the distribution.

content.raw:
@mlibbrecht Would you happen to know how GMTK handles negative values?

Also, doesn't this transformation still modify the shape of the data if it looks like a Gaussian? For example, outliers will have a +/-3 value, but the mean will have a 0 value.
content.html:
@mlibbrecht Would you happen to know how GMTK handles negative values?

Also, doesn't this transformation still modify the shape of the data if it looks like a Gaussian? For example, outliers will have a +/-3 value, but the mean will have a 0 value.

content.raw:
z(x) = (x - mean) / standard deviation

Zero-valued data will get a negative z-score.
content.html:
z(x) = (x - mean) / standard deviation

Zero-valued data will get a negative z-score.

content.raw: No, I don't know the reason for the oscillation. However, I don't think we should read into the simpleseg results because simpleseg is generated from a model with zero variance. If you're worried about this behavior, you should try on data for which you have injected some noise.
content.html: No, I don't know the reason for the oscillation. However, I don't think we should read into the simpleseg results because simpleseg is generated from a model with zero variance. If you're worried about this behavior, you should try on data for which you have injected some noise.

content.raw: @mlibbrecht this transform effectively inverts the shape of the data if it's looks like a gaussian correct? Since the farther away a datapoint is from the mean, the larger its zscore? For all zero-valued data for a given track - this means that there will be potentially a high zscore value?
content.html: @mlibbrecht this transform effectively inverts the shape of the data if it's looks like a gaussian correct? Since the farther away a datapoint is from the mean, the larger its zscore? For all zero-valued data for a given track - this means that there will be potentially a high zscore value?

content.raw: In general, should these means and variences be calculated on a per-window basis? I feel like if zscore is enabled, all the genomedata archives / tracks should have their variances and means figured out track-wide. @rcwchan can you look into this?
content.html: In general, should these means and variences be calculated on a per-window basis? I feel like if zscore is enabled, all the genomedata archives / tracks should have their variances and means figured out track-wide. @rcwchan can you look into this?

content.raw: @mlibbrecht I'm not sure this is calculating the variance. I think you're missing a term if you're expanding out the distance between the mean and the and the datapoint squared.
content.html: @mlibbrecht I'm not sure this is calculating the variance. I think you're missing a term if you're expanding out the distance between the mean and the and the datapoint squared.

content.raw: These last two are not in alphabetical order like the previous lines.
content.html: These last two are not in alphabetical order like the previous lines.

content.raw: It looks like simpleseg can take up to nearly 100 rounds with multiple instances with `--zscore` enabled. @mlibbrecht do you have any idea why? Why is there such a large chance of having such a difficult time to converge? @rcwchan can you post the liklihood progression of the instances with the large number of rounds?
content.html: It looks like simpleseg can take up to nearly 100 rounds with multiple instances with --zscore enabled. @mlibbrecht do you have any idea why? Why is there such a large chance of having such a difficult time to converge? @rcwchan can you post the liklihood progression of the instances with the large number of rounds?

update.description:
This pull request separates the --zscore option from [pull request #68](#!/hoffmanlab/segway/pull-requests/68/gaussian-mixture-models/). Note: I have not changed anything about the zscore functionality except attempting to adapt it for the multiple genomedata case.

It was suggested to move the zscore option to a separate distribution, ie, ```DISTRIBUTION_ZSCORE_ASINH```.
